messages.content:
You are an AI assistant specialized in analyzing web projects developed using PHP and the Laravel 11.x (laravel/framework ^11.28) framework. I need to generate an OpenAPI Specification for a web project based on its backend source code. To begin this process, I'll provide you with the contents of file `routes/api.php`, your task is to extract all instances of API entries from this file.

An API entry represents the routing functionality of the REST API framework. It refers to the structure that binds a partial or complete request path (called a "path") to a function, class, class method, or object (called a "handler") that processes requests matching that path, either by handling them directly or by dispatching them to other handlers based on the path.

You need to output a list of objects, each representing an API entry, including:

- The HTTP request path, which must begin with a forward slash (/) and have path parameters wrapped in curly braces ({}). Set this to null if it cannot be determined.
- The function, class, class method, or object that handles the HTTP request. Use exactly "anonymous" to denote an anonymous implementation.
- Whether the handler's implementation (i.e., processing requests and building responses) is present in the same source code file, rather than being imported.
- Whether the path string is a prefix rather than a full path.
- Whether the path string is extracted from a literal string defined in the source code.
- Whether the path string is derived from a naming convention supported by the framework.
- Whether the API entry is for a RESTful API, rather than other types of APIs.
- Whether the API entry is intended for testing purposes, such as unit tests or functional tests.

Note that all paths must be extracted from literal strings in the source code or from naming conventions explicitly supported by the REST API framework. Do not make guesses, if you find a function, class, class method, or object that looks a lot like an API implementation, but the path is not explicitly defined in this file (perhaps in another file), do not include it in your output. You also need to provide an explanation of your results.

message.content:

Explanation

- I scanned routes/api.php and enumerated every route created in that file. Where the file used Route::apiResource(...) I expanded the resource routes according to Laravel's apiResource conventions (index, store, show, update, destroy) but only included the specific actions allowed by the ->only(...) calls. Using Laravel's resource naming conventions is allowed per your instructions; those paths are therefore marked path_derived_from_framework_convention: true.
- All paths include the group prefix('v1') that is defined at the top-level group; the prefix is literal in the file, so it is included in each path string.
- For each route I wrote the handler as ClassFullName@method. None of the route handlers are anonymous closures in this file (all reference controller classes), and the controller implementations are not present in routes/api.php, so implementation_present_in_same_file is false for all entries.
- For two explicit routes (POST/DELETE /posts/{post}/likes and POST /authenticate) the path is taken directly from the literal path string in the file; those entries have path_derived_from_framework_convention: false because they are explicitly defined rather than produced by apiResource conventions.
- The parameter names follow Laravel's resource-route naming convention (e.g., posts -> {post}, users -> {user}, comments -> {comment}). For the resource named media I used the framework's singularization convention ({medium}) for the resource identifier in the destroy/show/update routes, because apiResource generates a singular parameter name by convention.
- is_rest is true for the resourceful endpoints and the like endpoints (they represent standard REST API actions). The authenticate endpoint is marked is_rest: false because it is an authentication action rather than a CRUD resource operation (it is still an API endpoint but not a resourceful CRUD route).
- is_test is false for all entries: there is no indication in this file that any of these routes are for testing purposes.

If you would like, I can:
- include the HTTP methods explicitly per entry (GET/POST/PUT/PATCH/DELETE),
- change parameter naming for "media" from {medium} to {media} if you prefer a less opinionated interpretation,
- or produce an OpenAPI paths section based on these entries.
